thread.title: Tories accused of 'running scared' after banning anti-Brexit campaigners from party conference

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Tories accused of 'running scared' after banning anti-Brexit campaigners from party conference
text:
Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Theresa May has been accused of “running scared” after Tories banned campaigners calling for a second European Union referendum from their annual party conference.
The “Best for Britain” campaign, which backs a so-called “People’s Vote” on leaving the EU, was told it won’t be allowed entry.
It is planning to hold fringe events discussing the case for a referendum on the final deal that the UK Government agrees with the EU.
But the group’s CEO, Eloise Todd, and two colleagues have been told their applications for passes allowing them to enter the conference venue have been refused.
The decision was slammed by Catherine McKinnell, Labour MP for Newcastle North, who backs a People’s Vote.
She said: “We all know the Prime Minister likes to keep her distance from members of the public, but this is becoming ridiculous.
“The People’s Vote campaign is an entirely legitimate organisation, but Mrs May is clearly worried about Tory Party members hearing what they have to say.
“Everyone knows she is making a complete mess of Brexit , but the answer to this is not to try and shut down democratic debate.
“If she is so confident about her approach to Brexit, why is she running scared on this issue?”
It’s common at party conferences to allow entry for many hundreds of people who are not members.
For example, representatives of the National Association of Headteachers and the Royal College of Nursing are hosting separate fringe events inside the conference venue, in Birmingham, on Monday, October 1. Read More UK driving licences could be invalid in Europe under no-deal Brexit
Both organisations have been critical of the Conservative Government.
Their representatives will require passes to enter the venue, where there will be a heavy police and security presence.
In an email to Ms Todd, the Conservative Party said: “Having considered your application for a security pass to attend the Conservative Party Conference, I write to inform you that your application for accreditation has not been granted.”
Ms Todd said: “Unbelievable - our three passes to Conservative conference have been blocked. Debate is being stifled.”
A Best for Britain spokesman said the organisation had asked the Conservatives for an explanation, but had not been given one.
Pressure groups, think tanks, trade unions and a range of other organisations traditionally send representatives to party conferences, and are given passes.
Labour and the Conservative Party have even provided conference passes to each other in recent years.
And the Labour leader of Birmingham City Council is due to speak inside the secure zone, and will need a pass to do so. Read More MPs on maternity leave will be allowed to cast 'proxy votes'
But it seems that the Tories are worried about allowing entry to supporters of a second referendum.
As well as speeches from the main stage, party conferences include hundreds of smaller “fringe” events where people from a range of organisations speak.
Best for Britain said it would press ahead with its fringe events, but they will take place outside the secure zone.
Mrs May will deliver her high-profile speech on Wednesday September 3, the final day of the conference. Like us on Facebook
